search.slidetext: family planning training package for health care providers general directorate of health programs and chronic diseases start start start

module 1: introduction to family planning this module gives an overview of family planning principle and methods as well as instructions on how to perform counseling sessions. it also emphasizes the importance of the client's choice and outlines the medical eligibility criteria for contraceptive methods use. in this module, will present three sessions that discuss the different subjects: session 1.1: family planning session 1.2: family planning counseling session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use
introduction session 1.1: family planning

learning objectives compare effectiveness of family planning methods. describe family planning methods (contraceptive methods). session 1.1: family planning by the end of this session, the participants are able to: assess effectiveness of family planning methods. define family planning. outline principles of family planning.

introduction: family planning it is the ability of a couple to anticipate and attain the desired number of children, and the spacing and timing of their births. it is achieved through the use of contraceptive methods and the treatment of involuntary infertility. family planning serves three necessary needs: session 1.1: family planning helps couples avoid unintended pregnancies. reduces the spread of sexually transmitted diseases (stds). addressing the problem of stds, it helps reduce rates of infertility. delaying pregnancies in young girls who are at increased risk of health problems from early childbearing, and preventing pregnancies among older women who also face increased risks. all these contribute to decrease in maternal illness and the incidence of pregnancy-related deaths.

principle 9: accountability principle 8: participation. principle 7: privacy and confidentiality. principle 6: informed decision-making. principle 5: quality. principle 4: acceptable information and services. principle 3: accessible information and services. principle 2: availability of contraceptive information and services. principle 1: non-discrimination. session 1.1: family planning principles of family planning click on each number to see more nine human rights principles guide family planning services. as a family planning provider, you contribute to all of them:

session 1.1: family planning methods of family planning (contraceptive methods) are the methods used either for spacing pregnancies or reduced the risk of unintended pregnancies. they could be a medication, a device, a procedure or even a behavior. usually categorized as either modern or traditional methods of contraception. modern methods of contraception include: female and male sterilization, intrauterine devices (iud), implants, injectables, oral contraceptive pills, male and female condoms, vaginal barrier methods (including the diaphragm, cervical cap and spermicidal foam, jelly, cream and sponge), the lactational amenorrhea method (lam), emergency contraception and other modern methods. traditional methods of contraception include: rhythm (e.g. fertility awareness-based methods, periodic abstinence), withdrawal and other traditional methods.
session 1.1: family planning methods of family planning (contraceptive methods)

note: sterilization, implants, and intrauterine devices are the most effective methods; the least effective ones are female condoms, spermicides, and withdrawal. session 1.1: family planning effectiveness of family planning methods these methods have different mechanisms of action and effectiveness in preventing unintended pregnancy. effectiveness of methods is measured by the number of pregnancies per 100 women using the method per year. very effective (0-0.9 pregnancies per 100 women). moderately effective (10-19 pregnancies per 100 women). effective (1-9 pregnancies per 100 women). less effective (20 or more pregnancies per 100 women. methods are classified by their effectiveness as commonly used into: click on the note icon to see more

implants, iud, female sterilization: after procedure, little or nothing to do or remember vasectomy: use another method for first 3 months injectables: get repeat injections on time lactational amenorrhea method (for 6 months): breastfeed often, day and night pills: take a pill each day patch, ring: keep in place, change on time male condoms, diaphragm: use correctly every time you have sex fertility awareness methods: abstain or use condoms on fertile days. newest methods (standard days method and two day method) may be easier to use. female condoms ,withdrawal, spermicides: use correctly every time you have sex female condoms ,withdrawal, spermicides: use correctly every time you have sex comparing effectiveness of family planning methods session 1.1: family planning less effective about 20 pregnancies per 100 more effective less than i pregnancy per 100 women in one year move the slider towards the arrow to know how to make your method more effective how to make your method more effective

learning objectives specify the characteristics of a successful family planning counselor. outlines the stages of family planning counseling. identify the various types of family planning clients. explain the family planning counseling approaches and the steps using the gather approach. demonstrate counseling process using video show. session 1.2: family planning counseling by the end of this session, the participants are able to: discuss the factors influencing counseling effectiveness. define family planning counseling, informed choices, and informed consent. describe the different types of family planning counseling.

introduction session 1.2: family planning counseling family planning counseling helps individuals and couples make informed decisions about their reproductive health by offering guidance on contraceptive options, fertility, and pregnancy planning. it empowers people to manage their reproductive health and plan their family size, contributing to a secure future for their families. will guide you through this lesson, how can you get a family planning services effectively.

is an interactive process that requires face-to-face communication between a skilled health provider and a client. its aim is to support the client in making an informed and voluntary decision by providing them with unbiased information that enables s/he to choose contraceptive method that is medically and personally appropriate and that s/he desires, understands how to use, and able used correctly for safe and effective contraception protection. note: it is somewhat different from advice, in which you try to solve a clients problem by giving information and your personal opinion. family planning counseling session 1.2: family planning counseling click on each icon to see more

informed consent is a consent given by a client after complete and correct information to accept and use the chosen method. it implies that a client has been counseled thoroughly regarding all the components described in the section on informed choice, and that based on this information, s/he has freely and voluntarily agreed to use the method s/he has chosen. informed consent is particularly important when a client chooses voluntary surgical contraception or any method that may have serious complications for a particular client (e.g. a woman over 35 who smokes and wants to use the coc). informed choice is an integral part of the counseling process and means that a client has the right to choose any family planning method s/he wishes, based on a clear understanding of the benefit and risks of all the available methods, including the option not to choose or adopt any method. the range of all methods available (this assumes that a variety of methods actually are available, or that an effort is made to obtain or refer). advantages/disadvantages of each. possible side effects/complications. precautions based on her individual medical history. information on risks of not using any method, such as risks associated with pregnancy/childbirth versus risks associated with contraceptive use. how to use the method chosen safely and effectively. in order to make a choice that is truly informed, the client needs to know: family planning counseling session 1.2: family planning counseling click on each icon to see more

individual counselling you will find that in most cases individuals prefer privacy and confidentiality during communication or counselling with you. it is important to respect the needs and interests of a client by finding a private place where you can talk with them. couple counselling is when you give a counselling service to a couple or partners together. this is particularly common when they are thinking of using irreversible family planning measures, such as voluntary surgical methods. session 1.2: family planning counseling types of family planning counseling click on each tab to see more

note: sometimes might not always be essential to pass through stage one, if already the client has been using methods. return/follow up counseling (post-choice stage) always be scheduled. addresses and manage any problems and side effects related to the chosen method. ensure user continuity of the chosen method, unless problems exist. discuss alternatives if the original method has not been satisfactory. instruction should be repeated. chance to find out whether the client has other concerns and question. click on the note icon to see more method-specific counseling (method-choosing stage) usually takes place after making an informed decision and method chosen. offer more information for the chosen method. assess and screens the client for using eligibility. educate the client on how and when to use method. ask the client to repeat the important information you discussed. specify when to return for follow-up or if there is a problem. give the client with a reminder card for following. general counseling (pre-choice stage) usually takes place on the first family planning visit. consist of general counseling. address the clients needs and concerns. provide broad information about methods given. clear up any mistaken beliefs or myths about specific family planning methods. help the client in making an informed choice regarding the most effective contraceptive method. additionally, may provide information on other sexual and reproductive health issues, like sexually transmitted infections (stis), involving hiv, and infertility. session 1.2: family planning counseling stages of family planning counseling click on each stage to see more
session 1.2: family planning counseling factors influencing counseling effectiveness health care provider related factors. client related factors. programmatic factors.

session 1.2: family planning counseling characteristic of effective family planning counselor 1. believes in and is committed to the basic values and principles of family planning and client rights. 2. always maintains clients' privacy and confidentiality. 3. listen carefully, listening is as important as giving correct information. 4. respect, accept, and deal with each client without passing judgment and maintain objectivity. 5. let the clients wishes and needs guide the discussion. 6. encourage the client to explain needs, express concerns, ask questions but prefer not to ask question with just yes or no answered. 7. poses questions clearly, using both open and close-ended questions. 8. give just key information and instructions. use words the client knows. 9. respect and support the clients informed decisions. 10. bring up side effects, if any, and take the clients concerns seriously. 11. check that the client understands. 12. invite the client to come back any time for any reason. a strong technical knowledge of contraceptive methods and the ability to apply effective interpersonal communication skills and counseling approaches are characteristics of an effective counselor. these techniques include the following:

the most effective counseling is customized for every client. client type usually counselling tasks returning clients with problems understand the problem and help resolve it-whether the problem is side effects, trouble using the method, an uncooperative partner, or another problem the most effective counseling is customized for every client. returning clients with no problems client type usually counselling tasks provide more supplies or routine follow-up ask a friendly question about how the client is doing with the method the most effective counseling is customized for every client. client type usually counselling tasks new clients with a method in mind check that the clients understanding is accurate support the clients choice, if client is medically eligible discuss how to use method and how to cope with any side effect new clients with no method in mind client type usually counselling tasks discuss the clients situation, plans, and what is important to her or him about a method help the client consider methods that might suit her or him. if needed, help her or him reach a decision support the clients choice, give instructions on use, and discuss how to cope with any side effects the most effective counseling is customized for every client. session 1.2: family planning counseling types of family planning clients clients seeking family planning might be categorized by method as follows: new clients who have no method in mind. new clients with a method in mind. clients returning for resupply (satisfied return clients). clients returning with problems or a different need (such as dissatisfied return clients). click on the arrows to see more

session 1.2: family planning counseling greet ask tell help explain, and return counseling approaches gather approach, stands for: there are various approaches can be used such as: redi approach, refers to: rapport exploration decision-making implementation of decision

r = return: schedule and carry out the clients return visit and follow-up visit. e = explain to client how to use the method. h = help client to make decision in choosing the preferred method. t = tell client about different contraceptive options and methods. a = ask client about family planning needs, concerns, and previous use. g = greet client in a friendly, helpful, and respectful manner. click on each card to see more. session 1.2: family planning counseling gather approach gather approach is the most commonly used type, the basic steps in gather approach counseling process are as follow: note: each step has tasks conducted under it and the counsellor should follow during the counseling process.
counseling process demonstration the video will demonstrate the steps involved in the counseling process. session 1.2: family planning counseling click on the video icon to see more

learning objectives identify importance of selected procedures for providing family planning methods. describe the categories for female sterilization and vasectomy. session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use explain a client assessment. define medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use. describe categories for temporary contraceptive methods use. by the end of this session, the participants are able to:

purpose of the medical eligibility criteria to: reduce medical barriers improve access and quality of care in family planning address misconceptions regarding who can and cannot safely use contraception base guidelines for family planning practices on the best available evidence each condition is defined as representing either an individuals characteristics (e.g., age, history of pregnancy) or known pre-existing medical (diabetes, hypertension). mec helps a provider to decide whether a particular contraceptive method can be used, in the presence of a given individual characteristic or medical condition. mec for starting use of contraceptive methods is based on who guidelines. medical eligibility criteria click on each number to see more session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use

each condition is defined as representing either an individuals characteristics (e.g., age, history of pregnancy) or known pre-existing medical (diabetes, hypertension) mec helps a provider to decide whether a particular contraceptive method can be used, in the presence of a given individual characteristic or medical condition mec for starting use of contraceptive methods is based on who guidelines medical eligibility criteria purpose of the medical eligibility criteria to: reduce medical barriers improve access and quality of care in family planning address misconceptions regarding who can and cannot safely use contraception base guidelines for family planning practices on the best available evidence session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use

category 4: a condition which represents an unacceptable health risk if contraceptive method is used. category 3: a condition where the theoretical or proven risks usually outweigh the advantages of using the method. category 2: a condition where the advantages of using the method generally outweigh the theoretical or proven risks. category 1: a condition for which there is no restriction for the use of the contraceptive method, use the method. categories for temporary contraceptive methods. click on each number to see more session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use
categories for temporary contraceptive methods use with clinical judgment session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use
categories for female sterilization and vasectomy session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use

client assessment the approach used to assess clients is to: verify that the client is not pregnant. determine whether the client has any conditions that preventing the use of a specific method. identify any special problems that require further assessment, treatment, or regular follow-up. session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use

assess if a client is medically eligible to use contraceptives. preform a systemic examination and check vital signs particularly blood pressure. history taking this is an essential component in client assessment as it provides. history taking: in particular, gynecological and obstetrical histories. this allows the service provider to have an overview of the client and makes it easier to discuss suitable family planning options. history taking this is an essential component in client assessment as it provides. history taking: in particular, gynecological and obstetrical histories. this allows the service provider to have an overview of the client and makes it easier to discuss suitable family planning options. client assessment move the slider to to see more steps in clients assessment session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use

criteria for excluding pregnancy she correctly and consequently used an efficient contraceptive method. she did not have sexual intercourse since her last menstrual bleeding. her menstrual period started within thelast 7 days. she had an abortion or miscarriage within the last 7 days. she gave birth within the last 6 months(the case of fully-breastfeeding woman who has not yet had a menstrual period). she gave birth within the last 4 weeks(the case of non-breastfeeding woman). 2. have you abstained from sexual intercourse since your last monthly bleeding, delivery, abortion, or miscarriage? 3. have you been using a reliable contraceptive method consistently and correctly since your last monthly bleeding, delivery, abortion, or miscarriage? 4. have you had a baby in the last 4 weeks? 5. did you have a baby less than 6 months ago, are you fully or nearly fully breastfeeding, and have you had no monthly bleeding since then? 1. did your last monthly bleeding start within the past 7 days?" 6.have you had a miscarriage or abortion in the past 7 days? if the client answered yes to at least one of the questions, you can be reasonably sure she is not pregnant if the client answered no to all of the questions, pregnancy cannot be ruled out using the checklist. rule out pregnancy by other means. if the client is planning to use a copper-bearing iud, the 7-day window is expanded to 12 days. the provider can be reasonable decide that a woman is not pregnant if she does not present pregnancy symptoms or signs and if she meets any of the following criteria: session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use

importance of selected procedures for providing family planning methods the following classification was used to differentiate between various tests and examinations that could be taken into consideration before starting contraceptives: most methods do not require any of these exams or tests (class c). no tests or examinations are needed before using fertility awareness-based methods, lactational amenorrhea method, or emergency contraceptive pills. these classifications apply to people who are presumed to be healthy. for a person with a known medical condition or other special condition, refer to annex 4 - medical eligibility criteria for contraceptive use. session 1.3: medical eligible criteria for contraceptive use

module 2: oral contraceptive pills oral contraceptive pills are a widely used as family planning method that give women a dependable and simple way to manage their reproductive choices. this module provides method-specific information on the variety of oral contraceptive methods that are accessible to women in saudi arabia . in this module, will present three sessions that discuss the different subjects: session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) session 2.2: progestin contraceptive pills (pops) session 2.3: emergency contraceptive pills (ecps) 1

learning objectives session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) by the end of this session, the participants are able to: define cocs and list their main characteristics. mention cocs types and dosages. list the cocs that are offered at the ministry of health - ksa. describe the use of cocs. specify when to begin using cocs. discuss the steps for managing missed cocs. identify coc side effects and provide guidance for management. assess client for cocs use. 2
session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) introduction 3

no protection against stis. immediately no delay. if used correctly, it's more than 99% (chance of failure are very low, less than 0.3% per year); however. if commonly used: its 92% (failure reaches 8%). prevents ovulation thickens the cervical mucus and preventing sperm penetration session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) main characteristics of cocs effectiveness effectiveness sexual transmitted infections (stis) sexual transmitted infections (stis) mode of action mode of action fertility return fertility return click on each section to see more 4

28 pillspack: not all pills are active, point out that the last 7 pills are a different color and inactive (do not contain hormones). 21 pillspack: all are active. very low dose: usually, given to women with very high risk if there is no alternative. high dose: not applicable due serious side effects of estrogen. standard (low) dose: pills with 3035 g estrogen and are the most commonly used by women. monophasic: all the pills in the pack contain the same quantity of estrogen and progestogen. biphasic and triphasic: the dose of estrogen and progestogen varies through pill cycle. session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) type and dose of cocs click on each tab to see more 5
session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) available cocs in ministry of health - ksa 6

if use the 28-pills pack: there is no waiting period between packs. once the client finished all the pills, a new pack starts the next day. if use the 21-pills pack: 7 days of no pills. once the client finished all the pills in the pack, wait 7 days before starting new pack. for example: if finished the old pack on saturday, take the first pill of the new pack on the next sunday. session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) how to use each cocs pack types click on each pack to see more 7

starting to use cocs are the methods used either for spacing pregnancies or reduced the risk of unintended pregnancies. they could be a medication, a device, a procedure or even a behavior. usually categorized as either modern or traditional methods of contraception. session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) 8

missed any non- hormonal pills (last 7 pills in a 28-pill pack) keep taking cocs, one each day, and start the new pack as usual. discard the missed non-hormonal pill(s). if pill missed in week 1 (1-7days) and she had sex in pill free week or week 1 then emergency contraception is needed. if pills missed in week 3 (15-21days), advice to finish all hormonal pills in the pack and throw away the 7 non-hormonal pills in a 28-pill pack and start a new pack the next day. also, if she had sex in the past 5 days, she can consider ecps. use a backup method for the next 7 days. take a hormonal pill as soon as remembers. if one has missed more than 7 consecutive days then consider as stopped cocs and start as new course. take a hormonal pill as soon as remembers. continue taking the remaining pill at usual time. no need for additional protection or emergency contraception. session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) managing missed coc pills with 3035 g estrogen click on each section to see more 9
session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) common side effects and complications of cocs click on each tab to see more 10

session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) managing any problem caused by the use of cocs problems reported as side effects or problems with use. may or may not be due to the method. consider the followings when managing side effects: problems with side effects affect womens satisfaction and use of cocs. reassure her, that many side effects will subside after a few months of initiating the cocs. encourage her to keep taking a pill every day even if she has side effects. for a woman whose side effects persist, give her a different coc formulation, if available, for at least 3 months. missing pills does might increase risk of pregnancy and worsen some side effects. as soon as possible, take a hormonal pill that you missed. treat any side effects according to recommended protocol in the guidelines. first, if suspected pregnancy, rule it out. offer to help the client choose another methodnow, if she wishes, or if problems cannot be overcome. 11

note in special circumstances (serious conditions mentioned before, however, when other, more appropriate methods are not available or acceptable to her, a qualified provider who can carefully assess a specific womans condition and situation may decide that she can use cocs. the provider needs to consider the severity of her condition and, for most conditions, whether she will have access to follow-up. session 2.1: combined oral contraceptive pills (cocs) a client assessment for the provision of cocs during the initial visit before providing the client withthe cocs, few steps mustbe done. these include: performing a physical examination that involvesvital signs, systemic examination. test and laboratory investigation they are not required for hormonal contraceptive methods. obtaining the client's histories menstrual, obstetrical and gynecological, medical, surgical, drug, and social histories. offering counseling to choose and agree upon the method use. offer counseling: help the client choose and agree on a method use. determining the client's medical eligibility to confirm her medical eligibility for coc use, the client must answer the question concerning coc use eligibility set by the world health organization. if she answers no to all of the questions, then she can start cocs if she wants. if she answers yes to a question, follow the instructions. in some cases she can still start cocs. nearly all women can use cocs safely and effectively, including women who: nearly all women can use cocs safely and effectively, including women who: are married, and have or have not had children. are of any age, including adolescents and women over 40 years old. after childbirth and during breastfeeding, after a period of time have just had an abortion, miscarriage, or ectopic pregnancy. are living with hiv, whether or not on antiretroviral therapy. have varicose veins. have anemia now or had in the past. smoke cigarettesif under 35 years old. generally, a woman with any of the conditions listed below should not use cocs: not breastfeeding and less than 3 weeks since giving birth, without additional risk that she might develop a blood clot in a deep vein (vte). not breastfeeding and between 3 and 6 weeks postpartum with additional risk that she might develop vte. primarily breastfeeding between 6 weeks and 6 months since giving birth. age 35 or older and smokes fewer than 15 cigarettes a day. click on the note icon to see more high blood pressure (systolic blood pressure between 140 and 159 mm hg or diastolic blood pressure between 90 and 99 mm hg). history of jaundice while using cocs in the past. gallbladder disease (current or medically treated). had breast cancer more than 5 years ago, and it has not returned. younger than age 35 and has migraine headaches without aura that have developed. age 35 or older and has migraine headaches without aura. diabetes for more than 20 years or damage to arteries, vision, kidneys, or nervous system caused by diabetes. multiple risk factors for arterial cardiovascular disease such as older age, smoking, diabetes, and high blood pressure. taking barbiturates, carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, phenytoin, primidone, topiramate, rifampicin, or rifabutin. taking lamotrigine. combined hormonal methods may make lamotrigine less effective. 12

session 2.2: progestin contraceptive pills (pops) managing missed pops if menses have returned and the client misses 1 or more pills by more than 3 hours (or 12 hours in the case of the 75 mg desogestrel-containing pills), regardless of whether or not she is breastfeeding. take 1 pill as soon as possible and continue taking the pills as usual, one each day. abstain from sex or use a backup method for the next 2 days. if she had sex in the past 5 days, she can consider taking ecps. if she vomits within 2 hours after taking a pill, she should take another pill from her pack as soon as possible, and keep taking pills as usual. if the client is breastfeeding and has amenorrhea, and she misses 1 or more pills by more than 3 hours (or 12 hours in the case of 75 mg desogestrel pills). take 1 pill as soon as possible and continue taking the pills as usual, one each day. if she is less than 6 months postpartum, no backup method is needed . start a new pack the next day. 22

session 2.3: emergency contraceptive pills (ecps) emergency contraceptive pills (ecps) a method used by a woman in order to help her avoid the risk of pregnancy after unprotected sex. unprotected sex includes situations when other methods fail, such as incorrect use of pills or injections, condom slips, and when an iud is expelled. ecps help to prevent pregnancy when taken up to 5 days after unprotected sex. the sooner they are taken, the better. they do not work if a woman is already pregnant. provide an opportunity for women to start using an ongoing family planning method. ecps are sometimes called morning after pills or post-coital contraceptives women say they like emergency contraceptive pills, because they: can be used as needed. reduce the need for abortion in the case of contraceptive errors or if contraception is not used offer a second chance at preventing unwanted pregnancy. enable a woman to avoid pregnancy if sex was forced or she was prevented from using contraception are controlled by the woman can have on hand in case the need arises. 31

no protection against stis. immediately no delay. effectiveness depends on when the dose is taken:if women had sex once during the second or third week of their menstrual cycle without use of contraception, effectiveness would be about 92%. if women used progestin-only ecps or ulipristal acetate ecps, effectiveness would be at 99% if women used combined estrogen and progestin ecps, effectiveness would likely 98% preventing or delaying ovulation, and may also interfere with implantation they have no adverse effect on an already existing pregnancy. session 2.3: emergency contraceptive pills (ecps) main characteristics of ecps click on each section to see more mode of action effectiveness fertility return sexual transmitted infections (stis) 32

if she chooses to use the 1.5 mg pill, must to be taken orally once within 72 hours of having unprotected sex. if she chooses to use the 0.75 mg pills, she must take one pill immediately and the second one after 12 hours; both must be taken within 72 hours of unprotected sex. box has one pill only (1.5mg) box has two pills (0.75mg) 1.5 mg 0.75 mg levonorgestrel tablets type and dose of ecps session 2.3: emergency contraceptive pills (ecps) click on each tab to see more 33

module 3: long acting reversible contraceptive methods this module's focus is on long-acting reversible contraceptives, which have been shown to be more cost-effective than other methods when used for more than a year. they also have the best potential to minimize unintended pregnancies and have good continuation rates. in this module, will present four sessions that discuss the different types of long-acting reversible contraceptive methods: session 3.1: injectables contraceptive methods session 3.2: combined patch session 3.3: implants session 3.4: intrauterine devices (iuds) 1

session 3.1: injectables contraceptive methods learning objectives by the end of this session, the participants are able to: define injectables and list their main characteristics. mention injectables types and dosages. list the injectables that are offered at the ministry of health - ksa. describe the use of injectables. specify when to begin using injectables. discuss the steps for managing late injectables. assess client for injectables use. 2

combined injectables (cics) combined injectables consists of 2 hormones - a progestin and an estrogen, which come in two forms: medroxyprogesterone acetate (mpa). estradiol cypionate and to norethisterone enanthate) (net-en) / estradiol valerate progestin-only injectables progestin-only injectables that contain a progestin similar to the hormone progesterone exists naturally in a woman's body. they are available in two forms: depot medroxyprogesterone acetate (dmpa). norethisterone enanthate (net-en). session 3.1: injectables contraceptive methods introduction injectables come in two types progestin-only injectables combined injectables (cics) click on each injectable to see more 3

session 3.1: injectables contraceptive methods introduction they also provide other non-contraceptive benefits such as reduce severity of symptoms of endometriosis (pelvic pain, irregular bleeding) prevent iron-deficiency anemia. protect against risks associated with endometrial cancer, uterine fibroids, and symptomatic pelvic inflammatory diseases (pid) reduce severity of sickle cell crises among women with sickle cell anemia. 4

sexual transmitted infections (stis) no protection against stis provided by any kind of injectables. fertility return for dpma and net-en, there is a 4-month and 1-month delay, respectively, after injections are stopped; in the case of monthly, this delay is one month longer than with most other methods (5 months). effectiveness (for both types of injectables) as commonly used, it ranges from 96-97%. within the first year. over the first year, women who receive their injections on schedule will experience efficacy rate of more than 99%. mode of action (for both types of injectables) act primarily by preventing the release of ova from the ovaries (ovulation). click on each section to see more mode of action fertility return effectiveness (for both types of injectables) sexual transmitted infections (stis) session 3.1: injectables contraceptive methods main characteristics of injectables progestin - only injectables and monthly injectables 5

session 3.1: injectables contraceptive methods managing late progestin only injectables if the client is up to 4 weeks late for a repeat injection of dmpa, or up to 2 weeks late for a repeat injection of net-en. she can receive her next injection. there is no need for tests, evaluation, or a backup method. a client who is more than 4 weeks late for dmpa or more than 2 weeks late for net-en. she can receive her next injection if: she has not had sex since 2 weeks after the scheduled date of her injection, or she has used a backup method or has taken ecps after any unprotected sex since 2 weeks after the scheduled date of her injection, or she is fully or nearly fully breastfeeding and she gave birth less than 6 months ago. however, in all three cases she will need a backup method for the first 7 days after the injection. 9

managing late monthly injectables if less than 7 days late for repeat injection. if more than 7 days late. she can receive her next injection if: she has not had sex since 7 days after her injection's scheduled date, or she has used a backup or taken ecps after unprotected sex since 7 days after her injections scheduled date. she will need a backup method for the first 7 days after the injection. she can receive her injection. no need for tests, evaluation, or backup method. if more than 7 days late and does not meet the previous conditions. additional steps can be taken to be reasonably certain she is not pregnant she will need a backup method for the first 7 days after injection. session 3.1: injectables contraceptive methods 10

steps for using the combined patch: session 3.2: combined patch prepare and unwrap the patch. apply into upper outer arm, back, stomach, abdomen, or buttock, wherever it is clean and dry, but not ion the breasts. then press the sticky, medicated part against her skin for 10 seconds. change the patch every week for 3 weeks in a row. apply each new patch on the same day of each week. do not wear a patch on the fourth week. after the patch free week, she should apply a new patch. never go without wearing a patch for more than 7 days. to avoid irritation, do not apply the new patch to the same place on the skin where the previous patch was. 17

the patch came off and was off for more than 2 days (more than 48 hours) ? apply a new patch as soon as possible, with the same patch-change day. and use a backup method for the next 7 days. if during third week, skip the patch-free week and start a new patch immediately after same week. if a new patch cannot be started immediately, use a backup method and keep using it through the first 7 days of patch use. if during first week and unprotected sex occurred in the past 5 days, consider taking ecps. the patch came off and was off for less than 2 days (48 hours or less) ? apply a new patch as soon as possible, with the same patch-change day. (the same patch can be reused if it was off less than 24 hours.) no need for a backup method. late taking off the patch at the end of week 3 ? remove the patch. start the next cycle on the usual patch-change day. no need for a backup method. late changing the patch at the end of week 1 or 2 ? if late by only 1 or 2 days, apply a new patch as soon as possible, and keep the same patch-change day. no need for a backup method. if more than 2 days late, apply a new patch as soon as possible. this patch will begin a new 4-week patch cycle, and this day of the week will become the new patch-change day. she needs to use a backup method for the next 7 days if more than 2 days late and unprotected sex occurred in the past 5 days, consider taking ecps. forgot to apply a new patch after the 7-day patch-free interval ? apply a new patch as soon as possible, and keep the same patch-change day. if more than 2 days late and no patch was worn for 10 days or more in a row, use a backup method for the first 7 days of patch use. if more than 2 days late and unprotected sex occurred in the past 5 days, consider taking ecps. %project.slidenumber% forgot to apply a new patch after the 7-day patch-free interval? forgot to apply a new patch after the 7-day patch-free interval? late changing the patch at the end of week 1 or 2? late changing the patch at the end of week 1 or 2? late taking off the patch at the end of week 3? late taking off the patch at the end of week 3? the patch came off and was off for less than 2 days (48 hours or less)? the patch came off and was off for less than 2 days (48 hours or less)? session 3.2: combined patch managing late replacement or removal, or if the patch comes off click on each situation to its managment the patch came off and was off for more than 2 days (more than 48 hours)? the patch came off and was off for more than 2 days (more than 48 hours)? 18

module 4: barrier contraceptive methods this module is designed to help healthcare providers develop the knowledge, attitudes, and skills necessary for effectively guiding clients on barrier contraceptive methods. additionally, it aims to build practical skills for providing clear, accurate information and addressing clients' questions and concerns about barrier contraceptives. in this module , three session will be presented: session 4.1: condoms (male and female) session 4.2: diaphragms session 4.3: cervical caps 1

session 4.1: condoms (male and female) define condoms and list their main characteristics. identify medical eligible criteria for condoms. explain how to manage if condom slips, is not used, or is used incorrectly. learning objectives by the end of this session, the participants are able to: 2

introduction the male condom is a thin latex rubber sheath or covering that fits over a mans erect penis to prevent sperm from entering the female genital tract. sexual transmitted infections (stis) and hiv can also be prevented by using it. sheath made of thin, transparent, soft film that is inserted inside the vagina before or at the time of intercourse to prevent pregnancy, stis, and hiv. it has 2 flexible rings, an inner ring at the closed end helps to insert the condom, and an outer ring at the open end holds the condom in position outside the vagina. there are 2 types of condom: session 4.1: condoms (male and female) 3
main characteristics of condoms session 4.1: condoms (male and female) 4

introduction the diaphragm is a soft latex cup that covers the cervix. the rim contains a firm, flexible spring that keeps the diaphragm in place. it is better to be used with spermicides to improve effectiveness. session 4.2: diaphragms 9

28 pillspack : not all pills are active, point out that the last 7 pills are a different color and inactive (do not contain hormones). 21 pillspack : all are active. very low dose pills: usually, given to women with very high risk if there is no alternative high dose: not applicable due serious side effects of estrogen. standard (low) dose pills: pills with 3035 g estrogen and are the most commonly used by women. monophasic: all the pills in the pack contain the same quantity of estrogen and progestogen. biphasic and triphasic: the dose of estrogen and progestogen varies through pill cycle. session 4.2: diaphragms main characteristics of diaphragms mechanism of action: act primarily by blocking sperm from entering the cervix. effectiveness: depends on the user: when used correctly with spermicide in every act of sex, its effectiveness over the first year is 84%. as commonly used with spermicide, its effectiveness over the first year is 83%. fertility return: no delay. protection against stis: none. 10

introduction is a soft, deep, latex or plastic rubber cup that snugly covers the cervix. it comes in different sizes and requires fitting by a specifically trained provider. session 4.3: cervical caps 15

28 pillspack : not all pills are active, point out that the last 7 pills are a different color and inactive (do not contain hormones). 21 pillspack : all are active. very low dose pills: usually, given to women with very high risk if there is no alternative high dose: not applicable due serious side effects of estrogen. standard (low) dose pills: pills with 3035 g estrogen and are the most commonly used by women. monophasic: all the pills in the pack contain the same quantity of estrogen and progestogen. biphasic and triphasic: the dose of estrogen and progestogen varies through pill cycle. main characteristics of cervical caps one of the more effective methods, as commonly used. as commonly used, its 84% effective during the first year especially if use with spermicide. when used correctly with every act of sex, its 91% effective over the first year. one of the least effective methods. as commonly used with spermicide, its 68% over the first year. when used correctly with every act of sex, its 74% over the first year. mechanism of action: act primarily by forming a physical barrier. fertility return: no delay. protection against stis: none. effectiveness: varies according to women birth status: session 4.3: cervical caps 16

28 pillspack : not all pills are active, point out that the last 7 pills are a different color and inactive (do not contain hormones). 21 pillspack : all are active. very low dose pills: usually, given to women with very high risk if there is no alternative high dose: not applicable due serious side effects of estrogen. standard (low) dose pills: pills with 3035 g estrogen and are the most commonly used by women. monophasic: all the pills in the pack contain the same quantity of estrogen and progestogen. biphasic and triphasic: the dose of estrogen and progestogen varies through pill cycle. medical eligible criteria for cervical caps session 4.3: cervical caps it is similar to the diaphragm. if she has cervical precancer or cancer do not provide cervical cap. 17

how to use cervical caps fill one-third of the cap with spermicidal cream, jelly, or foam. press the rim of the cap around the cervix until it is completely covered, pressing gently on the dome to apply suction and seal the cap. insert the cervical cap any time up to 42 hours before having sex. the client should leave the cervical cap in for at least 6 hours after her husbands last ejaculation, but not more than 48 hours from the time it was put in. leaving the cap in place for more than 48 hours may increase the risk of toxic shock syndrome and can cause vaginal discharge. tip the cap rim sideways to break the seal against the cervix, and then gently pull the cap down and out of the vagina. session 4.3: cervical caps 18

module 5: natural contraceptive methods this module is designed to equip healthcare providers with the knowledge, attitudes, and skills necessary to effectively guide clients on natural contraceptive methods. it also aims to build practical skills for delivering clear, accurate information and addressing clients' questions and concerns related to these methods. in this module , three session will be presented: session 5.1: lactational amenorrhea (lam) session 5.2: fertility awareness methods (calendar-based, symptoms-based, ovulation) session 5.3: withdrawal 1

learning objectives explain when can a woman use lam and how to use. by the end of this session, the participants are able to: define lactational amenorrhea (lam) and list their main characteristics. identify medical eligible criteria of lactational amenorrhea method. session 5.1: lactational amenorrhea (lam) 2

introduction session 5.1: lactational amenorrhea (lam) she is fully or nearly fully breastfeeding,and fed often, day and night. the baby is less than 6 months old. this method performs effectively if the nursing woman meets the following criteria: the mother has amenorrhea. the lactational amenorrhea method (lam), a temporary family planning method based on the natural effect of breastfeeding on fertility. 3

none depends on how long the woman continues to breastfeed. depends on the user: as commonly used, it might reach up to 98% within the first 6 months after childbirth. depends on the user: when used correctly more than 99% effective within the first 6 months after childbirth. frequent breastfeeding temporarily prevents the release of the natural hormones that cause ovulation. click on each section to see more mechanism of action fertility return effectiveness protection against stis session 5.1: lactational amenorrhea (lam) main characteristics of lactational amenorrhea method 4

the newborn has a condition that makes it difficult to breastfeed: including being small-for-date or premature and needing intensive neonatal care, unable to digest food normally, or having deformities of the mouth, jaw, or palate. is using certain medications during breastfeeding: including mood-altering drugs, reserpine, ergotamine, anti-metabolites, cyclosporine, high-dose corticosteroids, bromocriptine, radioactive drugs, lithium, and certain anticoagulants. has hiv infection: should use condoms along with the lam to prevent transmission of hiv and other stis. if she is not taking art therapy, she will transmit hiv to her infant through breastfeeding. medical eligible criteria for lactational amenorrhea method session 5.1: lactational amenorrhea (lam) a client's assessment for the use of lactational amenorrhea method based on who medical eligible criteria. is using certain medications during breastfeeding the newborn has a condition that makes it difficult to breastfeed has hiv infection all breastfeeding women can safely use this methods but a woman with the following circumstances may need to consider other contraceptive methods. click on each section to see more 5

if the answer to any one of these questions is yes her chances of pregnancy increase. advise her to begin using another family planning method and to continue breastfeeding for the child's health. if the answer to all of these questions is no she can use lam. there is only a 2% chance of pregnancy at this time. a woman may choose another family planning method at any time-but preferably not a method with estrogen while her baby is less than 6 months old. when can a woman use lam? session 5.1: lactational amenorrhea (lam) ask the mother these following three questions: is your baby more than 6 months old? has your monthly bleeding returned? are you regularly giving the baby other food besides breast milk or allowing long periods without breastfeeding, either day or night? if the answer to all of these questions is no click on each answer to see more if the answer to any one of these questions is yes 6

plan follow-up visit plan for the next visit while the lam criteria still apply, so that she can choose another method and continue to be protected from pregnancy. start other foods at 6 months she should start giving other foods in addition to breast milk when the baby is 6 months old. at this age, breast milk can no longer fully nourish a growing baby. if a client is breastfeeding often an ideal pattern is feeding on demand and at least 10 to 12 times a day in the first few weeks after childbirth and thereafter 8 to 10 times a day, including at least once at night in the first months. daytime feedings should be no more than 4 hours apart, and night-time feedings no more than 6 hours apart. how to use (lam)? session 5.1: lactational amenorrhea (lam) a client's assessment for the use of lactational amenorrhea method based on who medical eligible criteria start other foods at 6 months plan follow-up visit if a client is breastfeeding often click on each section to see more 7

learning objectives define fertility awareness method and list their main characteristics. identify medical eligible criteria for calendar and symptoms -based methods. explain how to use the calendar-based method (standard days method and calendar rhythm method). explain how to use the symptoms-based method (cervical secretions and basal body temperature). by the end of this session, the participants are able to: session 5.2: fertility awareness methods 9
introduction session 5.2: fertility awareness methods 10

protection against stis none effectiveness as commonly used, about 85% depending on the womans ability to identify her fertile phase. pregnancy rates with consistent and correct use vary for different types of fertility awareness methods. mechanism of action act primarily by avoiding unprotected sex during the fertile days usually by abstaining or using condoms or other suitable contraceptive methods. click on each section to see more mechanism of action effectiveness protection against stis main characteristics of fertility awareness method session 5.2: fertility awareness methods 11

medical eligible criteria for calendar and symptoms -based methods session 5.2: fertility awareness methods menstrual cycles are irregular recently had an abortion or miscarriage recently gave birth or is breastfeeding taking any drugs that change cervical secretions or make the menstrual cycle irregular all women can use these methods. no medical conditions prevent the use of these methods, but some conditions can make them harder to use effectively, for example: 12

how to use standard days methods session 5.2: fertility awareness methods each bead represents a day of the menstrual cycle. 3. use memory aids if needed the couple can mark a calendar or use other memory aids. 2. avoid unprotected sex on days 8-19 days 8 through 19 of every cycle are considered fertile days for all users of the standard days method. the couple avoids sex or uses condoms or a diaphragm during days 8 through 19. the couple can have unprotected sex on all other days of the cycle-days 1 through 7 at the beginning of the cycle and from day 20 until her next monthly bleeding begins. 1. keep track of the days of the menstrual cycle she keeps track of the days of her menstrual cycle, counting the first day of monthly bleeding as day 1. this method is appropriate for women whose menstrual cycles are usually between 26 and 32 days long. the next day move the ring to the next bead. do this every day, even bleeding days. white bead days are days when the woman can become pregnant. she should avoid unprotected sex. if monthly bleeding does not begin before reaching the last brown bead, her menstrual cycle is longer than 32 days. if monthly bleeding begins again before reaching the dark brown bead, her menstrual cycle is shorter than 26 days. brown bead days are days when pregnancy is unlikely and she can have unprotected sex. on day i-the first day of monthly bleeding-move the rubber ring to the red bead. 13

update calculations monthly she updates these calculations each month, always using the 6 most recent cycles. avoid unprotected sex during the fertile time the couple avoids sex or uses condoms or a diaphragm during the fertile time. estimate the fertile time she subtracts 18 from the length of her shortest recorded cycle. this tells her the estimated first day of her fertile time. then she subtracts 11 days from the length of her longest recorded cycle. this tells her the estimated last day of her fertile time. keep track of the days of the menstrual cycle before relying on this method, she records the number of days in each menstrual cycle for at least 6 months. click on each section to see more how to use calendar-rhythm method session 5.2: fertility awareness methods how to use calendar-rhythm method 3. avoid unprotected sex during the fertile time 4. update calculations monthly 1. keep track of the days of the menstrual cycle 2. estimate the fertile time 14

resume unprotected sex after 2 dry days the couple can have unprotected sex again after the woman has had 2 dry days (days without secretions of any type) in a row. note: if a woman has a vaginal infection or other condition that changes cervical mucus, the two day method will be difficult to use. avoid sex or use another method on fertile days the couple avoids sex or uses condoms or a diaphragm on each day with secretions and on each day following a day with secretions. they can also use withdrawal or spermicides, but these are less effective. check for secretions she checks for cervical secretions every afternoon and/or evening. as soon as she notices any secretions, she considers herself fertile that day and the following day. how to use symptoms-based method two-day method avoid sex or use another method on fertile days resume unprotected sex after 2 dry days check for secretions click on each section to see more session 5.2: fertility awareness methods 15

how to use basal body temperature (bbt) method session 5.2: fertility awareness methods avoid sex or use another method until 3 days after the temperature rise how to use basal body temperature (bbt) method take body temperature daily at the same time each morning she records her temperature on a special graph and watches for her temperature to rise slightly 0.2 c to 0.5 c just after ovulation. resume unprotected sex until next monthly bleeding begins when the womans temperature has risen above her regular temperature and stayed higher for 3 full days, ovulation has occurred and the fertile period has passed. the couple can have unprotected sex on the fourth day note: if woman has fever or other changes in the body temperature, the bbt method will be difficult to use. 16

learning objectives explain how to use withdrawal method. by the end of this session, the participants are able to: define withdrawal and list its main characteristics. identify medical eligible criteria of withdrawal method. session 5.3: withdrawal 18

introduction session 5.3: withdrawal just before ejaculation, the man withdraws his penis from his partners vagina and ejaculates outside the vagina, keeping his semen away from her external genitalia. also known as coitus interruptus and pulling out. one of the least effective contraceptive methods, some men use this method effectively. offers better pregnancy protection than no method at all. always available in every situation. can be used as a primary method or as a backup method. requires no supplies and no clinic or pharmacy visit. 19

protection against stis: none effectiveness risk of pregnancy is greatest when the man does not withdraw his penis before he ejaculates with every act of sex. when used correctly with every act of sex, it is 96% effective over the first year for the women whose partners use withdrawal. as commonly used, it is 80% effective over the first year for the whose partners use withdrawal fertility return never suppressed. click on each section to see more fertility return effectiveness protection against stis main characteristics of withdrawal method session 5.3: withdrawal 20

medical eligible criteria for withdrawal method session 5.3: withdrawal all men can use withdrawal. no medical conditions restrict a clients eligibility to use. withdrawal may be especially appropriate for couples who: have no other method available at the time. have objections to using other methods have sex infrequently. are waiting to start another method 21

explaing how to use withdrawal method inform the client that he can use the withdrawal method at any time, and that there is no contraindication to its use. tell him that if he wants to increase the effectiveness of withdrawal, he may combine it with other methods. explain that in case ejaculation takes place before withdrawing, emergency contraceptive pills (ecp) should be used . session 5.3: withdrawal 1. when the man feels close to ejaculating he should withdraw his penis from the womans vagina and ejaculate outside the vagina 2. if the man has ejaculated recently before sex he should urinate and wipe the tip of his penis to remove any remaining semen 3.giving advice on use 22

module 6: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv to protect the sexual health and well-being of clients with stis, it is important to recognize and respond to their specific needs. selecting a contraceptive method might affect not just preventing conception but also controlling and transmitting stis including hiv. in this module, will discuss: session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv 1

identify the prevention measures to avoid stis. explain dual protection strategy used for clients with stis. explain what family planning methods can be used by clients with stis. define sexually transmitted infections (stis). identify who is at risk for sexually transmitted infections. (stis). by the end of this session, the participants are able to: learning objectives session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv 2

sexually transmitted infections, including hiv session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv sexually transmitted infections (stis) are caused by bacteria, viruses, and parasites that are spread through sexual contact. most stis either cause no symptoms or show symptoms that can easily go unnoticed. certain stis can cause pelvic inflammatory disease, chronic pelvic pain, infertility, and cervical cancer in women, as well as infertility, anorectal and prostate cancer in men. in addition, some stis significantly raise the risk of having hiv. 3

there are some sexual practices and other behaviors that increase the risk of getting an sti, including hiv such as any sexual practice with a partner who has sti symptoms, or who has been diagnosed or treated for an sti in the past 6 months. any sexual practice extra-marital relationship without condoms in the past 6 months , the more partners, the greater the risk. exposure to contaminated needles from injection drug use or other (such as occupational exposure). session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv who is at risk for stis? 4

dual protection strategy session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv family planning providers can talk to clients about how they can protect themselves both from stis, including hiv, and from pregnancy by choosing dual protection strategy the decision to use particular prevention method (s) should be an informed choice, made voluntarily by the client. it is important to remember that clients might choose to use different strategies in different situations as well as at different times in their lives. the best strategy is the one that a person can practice effectively. 5

if both partners know that they are not infected with any stis, or if one partner is living with hiv but has achieved viral suppression through antiretroviral therapy (art), then use any family planning method to prevent pregnancy and agree to stay in a mutually faithful relationship. many family planning clients believe they are in this group and thus feel protected from stis, including hiv, without using condoms. this strategy depends on good communication and trust between partners. use male or female condoms consistently and correctly plus another family planning method: using two methods provides extra protection from pregnancy in case the condom is not used, is used incorrectly, or breaks. this strategy may be a good choice for those who want to feel reassured about avoiding pregnancy if they cannot always be sure of consistent and correct condom use. use male or female condoms consistently (with every sex act) and correctly: one method is used to help protect against both pregnancy and stis. dual protection strategy click on each tab to see more session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv 6

contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv all hormonal methods (except hormone-releasing iuds) can be used by any client with stis, including hiv. clients with stis and hiv can start and keep using the majority of contraceptive methods safely, whether or not they are using art. session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv 7

can be used. generally, clients living with hiv should not use spermicides (the risks usually outweigh the advantages). a client living with mild hiv (who stages 1 or 2), including a client on antiretroviral therapy (art), can have an iud inserted a client should not have an iud inserted if they have severe or advanced hiv (who stages 3 or 4). a current iud user who becomes infected with hiv or whose hiv severe or advanced (who stages 3 or 4) can safely continue using the iud. a client using an iud can keep the iud in place when they start art. do not insert an iud in a client who is at high risk for gonorrhea and chlamydia, or who currently has gonorrhea, chlamydia, or pelvic inflammatory diseas (pid). however, a current iud user who becomes infected with gonorrhea or chlamydia or develops pid can safely continue using the iud during and after treatment for the infection. there are a few limitations for using this methods, described in the following table spermicides intrauterine device (iud): copper-bearing iud or levonorgestrel containing iud session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv click on each arrow to see more 8

avoiding stis (continue) other sti preventive measures include: hpv vaccine hepatitis b vaccine pre-exposure prophylaxis (prep) post-exposure prophylaxis (pep) male circumcision lubricants: prevent micro tears in the mucosa, which can create entry points for stis. water-based lubricants are recommended when used with condoms. condoms : the correct and consistent use of male or female condoms offers effective protection against stis, including hiv. male condom may prevent 80% to 95% of hiv transmission that would have occurred without condoms. avoiding stis family planning providers can assist their clients in various ways to prevent stis, including hiv for example: session 6.1: contraceptives for clients with stis, including hiv click on each button to see more 9
